Theorie der großen Abweichungen für selt: Theory of large deviations for rare events and exponential decay rates; i.i.d. sequences and empirical measures; applications in ergodic theory, information theory, and statistical physics. Workload 150 h (45 h contact), 5 ECTS, irregular. Version 2021s responsible: Gantert, Nina.
Lernende beherrschen zentrale Large-Devi: Learners master central large deviation principles for i.i.d. sequences and empirical measures and apply exponential estimates in typical applications.
Lernende erläutern Zielsetzung der Large: Learners explain the goal of large deviation theory, know exponential inequalities, and link decay rates to rare events.
Lernende formulieren und nutzen Large-De: Learners formulate and use large deviation principles for sums of i.i.d. random variables incl. rate functions.
Learners formulate and use large deviation results for empirical measures and interpret the associated rate functions.
Lernende wenden Large-Deviation-Technike: Learners apply large deviation techniques to examples from ergodic theory, information theory, and statistical physics.
Continuum kinematics and balance laws; h: Continuum kinematics and balance laws; hydrodynamics with viscosity, Bernoulli and lift; flow regimes across Reynolds numbers; waves; linear elasticity, deformation tensors, elastic waves, and thin-body limits. Workload 300 h (90 h contact), 10 ECTS, winter term. Version 2025w responsible: Gerland, Ulrich. Language: EN.
Learner understands continuum kinematics: Learner understands continuum kinematics and balances, hydrodynamics with viscous effects and flow regimes, and elasticity including waves and thin-body reductions.
Learner can describe velocity fields of: Learner can describe velocity fields of continua, continuity equations, and balance laws for mass/momentum/energy for simple systems.
Learner can apply hydrodynamic equations: Learner can apply hydrodynamic equations with viscosity/stress tensor, Bernoulli’s equation, lift on moving bodies, and discuss viscous effects.
Learner can distinguish laminar vs turbu: Learner can distinguish laminar vs turbulent flow, analyze high/low Reynolds regimes, and describe basic wave phenomena in fluids.
Learner can use deformation tensors, ene: Learner can use deformation tensors, energy balance, and equations of linear elasticity to describe deformations and elastic waves.
Learner can explain phenomena arising fr: Learner can explain phenomena arising from reducing extended media to one- or two-dimensional models (thin bodies, shells, membranes).
Path integrals (classical/semiclassical: Path integrals (classical/semiclassical limit, Aharonov–Bohm), open quantum systems (density matrices, Lindblad, decoherence), identical particles and second quantization, Klein–Gordon and Dirac equations, relativistic corrections (spin–orbit, Darwin, Lamb shift), and molecular Born–Oppenheimer/van der Waals (time permitting). Workload 150 h (90 h contact), 5 ECTS, offered in winter term. Version 2025w responsible: Brambilla, Nora. Language: EN/DE.
Learner can handle path integrals, open-: Learner can handle path integrals, open-system dynamics, second quantization for identical particles, relativistic one-particle equations, and key relativistic corrections, with awareness of decoherence and molecular approximations.
Learner can set up path integrals, conne: Learner can set up path integrals, connect to classical/semiclassical limits, and explain the Aharonov–Bohm effect.
Learner can use density matrices, von Ne: Learner can use density matrices, von Neumann/Lindblad equations, and discuss decoherence including two-level systems.
Learner can formulate bosonic/fermionic: Learner can formulate bosonic/fermionic systems with Fock space, second quantization, and interpret one-/multi-particle operators and field operators.
Learner can derive/solve Klein–Gordon an: Learner can derive/solve Klein–Gordon and Dirac equations, discuss operators (Hamiltonian, momentum, charge current) and couplings to electromagnetism.
Learner can compute the Dirac energy spe: Learner can compute the Dirac energy spectrum for hydrogen and relate it to gyromagnetic ratio and Pauli equation limits.
Learner can derive nonrelativistic expan: Learner can derive nonrelativistic expansions (spin–orbit, Darwin term, Lamb shift) and interpret their spectral effects.
Learner can quantize electromagnetic, Kl: Learner can quantize electromagnetic, Klein–Gordon and Dirac fields, and use number/occupation representations in Fock space.
Learner understands Born–Oppenheimer app: Learner understands Born–Oppenheimer approximation and van der Waals forces for molecular states (if time permits).
Mathematics of Climate and Earth System: Mathematics of Climate and Earth System Sciences (TUM, Module ED110088)
Mathematical analysis and modeling of no: Mathematical analysis and modeling of nonlinear processes in the climate and Earth system: nonlinear/chaotic dynamics, analytical and numerical methods, time-series analysis, stochastic and non-autonomous systems, and tipping-point phenomena. Workload 270 h (90 h contact), 9 ECTS, offered in winter term. Version 2023s responsible: Boers, Niklas.
Math of Climate & Earth System – Module: Math of Climate & Earth System – Module Overview
Learner masters mathematical tools for n: Learner masters mathematical tools for nonlinear climate/Earth-system processes, including dynamical systems, stochastic modeling, time-series methods, and tipping-point analysis.
Learner can analyze nonlinear and chaoti: Learner can analyze nonlinear and chaotic dynamical systems relevant to the climate/Earth system using analytical and numerical tools.
Learner can derive and analyze core flui: Learner can derive and analyze core fluid-mechanics equations and apply analytical/numerical techniques to Earth-system problems.
Learner can rigorously analyze time seri: Learner can rigorously analyze time series from climate/Earth-system processes, with a focus on nonlinear dynamics.
Learner can explain stochastic and non-a: Learner can explain stochastic and non-autonomous dynamical systems and apply stochastic differential-equation concepts to Earth-system modeling.
Learner can identify and assess critical: Learner can identify and assess critical transitions and tipping points in Earth-system models, linking theory to observed or simulated time series.
Nichtlineare Dynamik und komplexe System: Nonlinear Dynamics and Complex Systems 1 (TUM, Module PH2027)
Foundations of low-dimensional nonlinear: Foundations of low-dimensional nonlinear dynamics: stability and bifurcations, self-sustained oscillations, limit cycles and Poincaré maps, routes to deterministic chaos, invariant measures and Lyapunov exponents, with hands-on numerical continuation and phase-space analysis. Workload 150 h (60 h contact), 5 ECTS, winter term. Version 2025w responsible: Krischer, Katharina. Language: EN.
Nonlinear Dynamics & Complex Systems – M: Nonlinear Dynamics & Complex Systems – Module Overview
Learner understands geometric phase-spac: Learner understands geometric phase-space methods for nonlinear ODEs, bifurcations, oscillations, routes to chaos, and can use numerical tools to analyze low-dimensional dynamical systems.
Learner can use geometric phase-space an: Learner can use geometric phase-space analysis to classify fixed points, assess stability, and describe bifurcations in 1D systems.
Learner can analyze oscillations in 2D s: Learner can analyze oscillations in 2D systems, identify limit cycles, and use Poincaré sections/maps to study their bifurcations.
Learner can explain routes to determinis: Learner can explain routes to deterministic chaos, characterize chaotic attractors via invariant measures and dimensions, and compute Lyapunov exponents.
Learner can use software for phase-space: Learner can use software for phase-space analysis and perform numerical continuation for 1D/2D bifurcation analysis of coupled ODEs.
Learner can connect nonlinear dynamics c: Learner can connect nonlinear dynamics concepts to examples across natural sciences and discuss bistability, oscillations, and chaos in applied contexts.
Advanced Earth System Modeling and Conti: Advanced Earth System Modeling and Continental Hydrology (TUM, Module ED110153)
Advanced Earth-system components and cou: Advanced Earth-system components and coupling; global hydrological and carbon cycles; land–atmosphere interactions; tipping points; hydrogeodetic observation techniques (radar/laser/Doppler altimetry, GNSS-R, GRACE/GRACE-FO, SWOT); inland water monitoring and data assimilation. Workload 150 h (60 h contact), 5 ECTS, offered in winter term. Version 2024s, responsible currently unspecified.
Advanced Earth System Modeling & Hydrolo: Advanced Earth System Modeling & Hydrology – Module Overview
Learner understands advanced Earth-syste: Learner understands advanced Earth-system modeling with coupled components, hydrological cycles, tipping-point risks, and hydrogeodetic observation/assimilation for inland waters.
Learner can describe modeling of atmosph: Learner can describe modeling of atmosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, biosphere and explain coupling strategies and associated uncertainties in state-of-the-art Earth system models.
Learner can explain global hydrological: Learner can explain global hydrological and carbon cycles and advanced modeling of land–atmosphere interactions, including uncertainty sources.
Learner can discuss Earth-system tipping: Learner can discuss Earth-system tipping points and critically reflect on uncertainties in coupled model setups.
Learner understands measurement principl: Learner understands measurement principles and use-cases of radar/laser/Doppler altimetry, GNSS-reflectometry, GRACE/GRACE-FO and SWOT for inland hydrology.
Learner can apply satellite altimetry to: Learner can apply satellite altimetry to estimate river discharge and lake volume changes and assess data quality for inland waters.
Learner can explain and apply assimilati: Learner can explain and apply assimilation/calibration of hydrological models with hydrogeodetic information, including numerical exercises on inland altimetry products.
Master-level module on concentration of: Master-level module on concentration of measure inequalities and techniques (Chernoff, Hoeffding, Bernstein, isoperimetric/Poincaré/Gromov–Milman, martingales/Azuma, Johnson–Lindenstrauss) with applications. Workload 150 h (45 h contact), 5 ECTS, offered irregularly. Version 2022s responsible: Warzel, Simone.
Students understand and can apply key co: Students understand and can apply key concentration of measure inequalities and techniques to examples relevant to theoretical/mathematical physics and probability.
Learner can state and apply classical co: Learner can state and apply classical concentration inequalities (Chernoff, Hoeffding, Bernstein) and isoperimetric inequalities.
Learner can use martingale techniques an: Learner can use martingale techniques and Azuma’s inequality for concentration in dependent settings.
Learner can explain Poincaré inequalitie: Learner can explain Poincaré inequalities, Gromov–Milman theorem and related functional/metric concentration results.
Learner can apply Johnson–Lindenstrauss: Learner can apply Johnson–Lindenstrauss inequality for dimensionality reduction and understand its concentration basis.
Learner can select and apply suitable co: Learner can select and apply suitable concentration tools to examples from the course (probability/physics contexts) and interpret results.
Core QFT concepts: path integrals and pe: Core QFT concepts: path integrals and perturbation theory with Feynman diagrams; Green functions to cross sections via LSZ; renormalization, regularization, effective field theory, RG and running couplings; symmetries and relativistic fields with spin, fermionic path integrals, general Feynman rules; vector fields and gauge symmetry, QED. Workload 300 h (150 h contact), 10 ECTS, winter term. Version 2023w responsible: Beneke, Martin. Language: EN/DE.
Learner can set up path-integral QFT, co: Learner can set up path-integral QFT, compute perturbative amplitudes and Green functions, perform renormalization/RG, and quantize gauge theories including QED.
Learner can formulate QFT in the path-in: Learner can formulate QFT in the path-integral approach, perform perturbative expansions, and build Feynman diagrams/rules.
Learner can relate Green functions to S-: Learner can relate Green functions to S-matrix elements and cross sections via LSZ and handle particle states in QFT.
Learner can regularize and renormalize p: Learner can regularize and renormalize perturbative QFT, use running couplings, and apply RG/improvement; understands EFT concepts.
Learner can quantize relativistic fields: Learner can quantize relativistic fields with spin, set up fermionic path integrals, and derive Feynman rules respecting symmetries.
Learner can quantize vector fields with: Learner can quantize vector fields with gauge symmetry, derive QED Feynman rules, and compute tree/loop processes in abelian and non-abelian settings.
Machine Learning in Earth System Modelin: Machine Learning in Earth System Modeling (TUM, Module ED110065)
Data-driven and process-based modeling o: Data-driven and process-based modeling of the Earth system: differential-equation models, linear/nonlinear/parametric/nonparametric approaches, inverse/data-driven modeling, RNNs/CNNs for dynamics, explainable and interpretable AI. Workload 90 h (30 h contact), 3 ECTS, offered each semester. Version 2022w responsible: Boers, Niklas.
Machine Learning in Earth System Modelin: Machine Learning in Earth System Modeling – Module Overview
Students understand foundations of Earth: Students understand foundations of Earth-system modeling and ML methods for dynamics, including explainable AI and hybrid process/data-driven modeling.
Learner can explain classical process-ba: Learner can explain classical process-based Earth-system modeling with differential equations and linear/nonlinear, parametric/nonparametric approaches.
Learner can describe inverse modeling an: Learner can describe inverse modeling and data-driven approaches for Earth-system components.
Learner can apply recurrent and convolut: Learner can apply recurrent and convolutional neural networks to dynamic modeling tasks in Earth-system contexts.
Learner can explain XAI methods and use: Learner can explain XAI methods and use them to identify Earth-system dynamics in neural models.
Learner can understand and critically as: Learner can understand and critically assess combinations of process-based and data-driven/ML models for Earth-system dynamics.
Theoretical Condensed Matter Physics (TU: Theoretical Condensed Matter Physics (TUM, Module PH1001)
Symmetries and phases of condensed matte: Symmetries and phases of condensed matter; phonons and response; electrons and transport (Bloch/Wannier, band theory, Hall effects); interacting electrons with screening and collective modes; superconductivity; quantum magnetism, Hubbard models, disorder/localization. Workload 300 h (90 h contact), 10 ECTS, winter term. Version 2025w responsible: Knolle, Johannes. Language: EN.
Learner can describe structures and phas: Learner can describe structures and phases of condensed matter and apply key models for lattice vibrations, electron bands/transport, interacting electrons, superconductivity, magnetism, and disorder.
Learner can classify phases of matter, r: Learner can classify phases of matter, relate scattering/structure factors to atomic composition, and discuss structural transitions/defects.
Learner can derive phonon spectra and sp: Learner can derive phonon spectra and specific heat, use inelastic neutron scattering/dynamic structure factors, and apply linear response and fluctuation–dissipation.
Learner can apply Bloch theorem and Wann: Learner can apply Bloch theorem and Wannier functions, classify metals/insulators/para-/diamagnetism, analyze semiclassical dynamics, Bloch oscillations, Drude/Boltzmann transport, and quantum Hall effects.
Learner can set up many-body description: Learner can set up many-body descriptions (second quantization), analyze electron gas/Lindhard function, Fermi liquid theory, HF, RPA, screening, and collective excitations.
Learner can explain electron–phonon coup: Learner can explain electron–phonon coupling and BCS theory of superconductivity, including collective modes.
Learner can discuss quantum magnetism, H: Learner can discuss quantum magnetism, Hubbard models (weak/strong coupling), and disorder/localization effects in condensed matter.
Phase transitions and critical phenomena: Phase transitions and critical phenomena, Landau–Ginzburg theory and fluctuations, renormalization group (fundamentals and applications), irreversible processes and nonequilibrium phenomena, percolation theory. Workload 300 h (90 h contact), 10 ECTS, offered in winter term. Version 2025w responsible: Alim, Karen. Language: DE/EN.
Learner can analyze critical phenomena,: Learner can analyze critical phenomena, apply Landau–Ginzburg and renormalization-group methods, and discuss nonequilibrium processes and percolation.
Learner can explain phase transitions an: Learner can explain phase transitions and critical phenomena and analyze systems using critical exponents.
Learner can explain Landau–Ginzburg theo: Learner can explain Landau–Ginzburg theory, incorporate fluctuations, and connect to critical behavior.
Learner understands RG basics, can apply: Learner understands RG basics, can apply RG to given systems, and interpret flow, fixed points, and scaling.
Learner can outline approaches to nonequ: Learner can outline approaches to nonequilibrium physics, compare irreversible processes, and discuss nonequilibrium universality.
Learner can describe percolation theory,: Learner can describe percolation theory, relate it to critical phenomena, and understand nonequilibrium universality classes.
Modern theoretical/computational methods: Modern theoretical/computational methods to calculate material properties from atomic structure: many-body foundations, Hartree–Fock, density-functional theory (DFT/TDDFT), many-body perturbation theory, ab-initio molecular dynamics, phonons, defects, charge/ion transport, and machine-learning approaches. Workload 300 h (~90 h contact assumed), 10 ECTS, offered in winter term. Version 2025w responsible: Egger, David. Language: EN.
Learner understands core ab-initio and c: Learner understands core ab-initio and computational methods (DFT/TDDFT, HF, many-body perturbation, MD, transport, ML) to predict and interpret material properties from atomic structure.
Learner can explain the many-body proble: Learner can explain the many-body problem, Hartree–Fock method, and adiabatic approximations as a basis for electronic-structure methods.
Learner can describe DFT and TDDFT forma: Learner can describe DFT and TDDFT formalisms, connect to many-body perturbation theory, and discuss strengths/limitations for materials.
Learner can compute/interpret phonons, v: Learner can compute/interpret phonons, vibration spectra, and defect calculations within ab-initio frameworks.
Learner can explain and apply force-fiel: Learner can explain and apply force-field and ab-initio molecular dynamics for materials, including adiabatic approximations.
Learner can describe charge/ion transpor: Learner can describe charge/ion transport models (band theory, ballistic, modern methods) and their computational treatment.
Learner understands basic ML concepts an: Learner understands basic ML concepts and applications for materials modeling, recognizing strengths and limitations.
